ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Gained the basic skills of literary analysis, and an overview of the French canon.

A got a great overview of 19th and 20th century French literature, getting to know some of the most emblematic writers in their literary and socio-historical  context. I developed an appreciation for style, technique, and voice, and I became very aware of how French writers continuously responded to their predecessors and contemporaries.
Learned about modern French literature, history of France, famous literary themes and movements
I learned more about analyzing literature and considering author choices like narration style, book structure, etc.

I was exposed to many classic French novels that were published during the 19th and 20th centuries, and learned the importance of French history in each story's central message. By taking the French section I was able to continue to develop my spoken and written French in a more practical setting.
History, authorship, and critical analyses of classic and new French novels.
I developed a really good understanding of modern french literature, and the authors and broad themes pertaining to the novels we read.
A knowledge of the seminal writers of the  French literary tradition, some French history and intellectual history
French, Literature analysis

This course is great at demonstrating connections between works in a particular cultural space through the eras; the professors know a ton about the historical context of every work, so the course feels like a real cohesive survey of French literary culture. Each work informs the next.
I learned a new way to read and look at literature.
I learned SO much in this class about the French literary tradition, historical context, and the biographies and approaches of different writers.
I learned about a bunch of French novels, as well as a handful of literary movements (realism and surrealism, for example). I improved my French and developed my French writing ability.
had a survey of modern french novel, learnt a lot about both literature and life
Overview of French literature
Under the guidance of two excellent specialists in literature, I had the opportunity to read amazing books from the French literature canon and discuss literary techniques.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed the course, it was structured very nicely in a chronological fashion and the way in. which the instructors entwined French history was enriching.
It definitely could have been structured a bit better, with more student-professor discussion of the novels instead of Q&A panels or lectures, as I felt that I was being talked at for hours in class.

The teaching is a huge strength of the course: profs Samuels and Kaplan prepare captivating, fun, and really insightful lectures and the Q&A/debate they hold at the end is a great way to keep everyone hooked. It goes without saying as well that the content of the class is a huge strength: the professors have curated a really great syllabus that builds a sense of historical, thematic, and literary progression.
Section was also very relaxed and a great time to come together to discuss the books, and my TA was really nice.
The only weakness I can think of is the heavy reading load at the beginning of the semester, but the class is made so that, if you aren't able to get through everything, you will not be lost, rather it will only feel like you are missing out on great reading.
No weaknesses! The class was taught exceptionally well. Really enjoyed the lectures as well as the discussions

If there could somehow be a French lecture offered as well, that would be helpful for those of us taking the French section who are also looking to practice French and more fully analyze the French language aspects of the books!
Adored this class. Highly recommend.
Strengths: professors are amazing lecturers

Strengths - reading selection
Weaknesses - the lectures were wonderful but a little too heavy on context sometimes
I really enjoyed the structure of the course and thought that the lecture were really engaging, I would have liked some more time for student questions during lectures though

Strengths: Professors Kaplan and Samuels are great, the books are great, and section was usually engaging and enjoyable.

Weaknesses: The choices of what to read were sometimes confusing; some of the books required prior knowledge of books not on the syllabus. As it's an introduction to French literature, they could have made it more accessible, or at least included prerequisite texts earlier in the syllabus.

The strength is that it connects history, politics, and literature. Also, it pushes me to read a lot.
But, I feel like we are reading too many books that we don't have enough time to dive deep into each of them... Maybe fewer books would be better?
Too many books perhaps, but very good ones.

Great reading list is a huge strength, but a weakness is that the reading load is fairly intense, especially during some weeks with denser texts. I loved the co-taught format in which one professor lectures for 40 mins and the other leads a 10 minute discussion after the fact, especially since they're both giants in their fields and have lots of insight to offer.
The course is well-taught and the material is strong. The sections were not particularly good, but I was in the French-speaking section, so it's hard to tell.

strength: lectures are engaging and interesting 
weakness: n/a
Interesting and wonderful, no weaknesses
The course is super well structured with plenty of opportunity for student engagement. I wish there were more opportunities for office hours.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, even for non-literature students.
It was a light course, but at times, the work seemed tedious and not really that conducive to student learning.
100% recommend. Perhaps this sounds pretentious but reading these books truly will change how you see all other art and literature.

Yes! This class is fun, enriching, and an opportunity to discover a great pleasure in French literature. The course is a joy regardless of how much you choose to dedicate yourself to it. Obviously you will get more out of the class if you read all of the books and engage with them critically, but even in weeks when you might fall behind, you will still be able to learn and enjoy simply by listening to the lectures.
Definitely! The course structure was great. The books we read were super interesting and the lectures were so amazing
Yes, the books are so interesting and touch on many important life lessons!

Yes, especially if you are studying French language and culture, familiarizing yourself with French classics is a must. It was also a great opportunity to continue practicing my French, both written and spoken.
Yes, Profs Samuels and Kaplan are excellent lecturers, and one of the most fulfilling English classes Ive taken at Yale.
Absolutely, must take at Yale, WR credit was doable. Lectures are quintessential Yale learning experience.
Absolutely - the professors are caring and very knowledgeable, great lecturers
Yes
Yes. Anyone who wants to read a bunch of great writers with a manageable workload will enjoy this classs.
If you are interested in classic literature, this is definitely a good course.
Yes!

Yes, but only if you're ready to commit to doing the readings. I always got everything done, but I was usually racing to finish up the last few chapters and feel like I probably missed some stuff along the way as a result.

Like any great books course, it's quite a lot of reading, with 150-200 pages a week. Other than showing up to lecture (at which they take attendance) and section, along with the handful of papers and tests they don't grade too harshly, it's pretty low-commitment. The lectures are good. If you can commit to doing the readings, I would recommend the Credit/D option.
yes, you'll truly learn a lot and reflect on your life with the novels. I enjoyed the readings.
Yes

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The course provides a basic framework for literature studies, and Prof Samuels and Prof Kaplan are both incredibly engaging lectures who also bounce off each other well.

extras.title: FREN 240 01/HUMS 201 01/LITR 214 01 - The Modern French Novel TR
